question:
Select the option that contains a grammatical error in the underlined portion.
He was always been a grumpy man so I never liked him and avoided his company.

(SSC CGL 2023 T-1 : 26 July Shift-3)
option_1: H̲e̲ ̲w̲a̲s̲ ̲a̲l̲w̲a̲y̲s̲ ̲b̲e̲e̲n̲ a grumpy man, so I never liked him and avoided his company.
option_2: He was always been a̲ ̲g̲r̲u̲m̲p̲y̲ ̲m̲a̲n̲, so I never liked him and avoided his company.
option_3: He was always been a grumpy man, s̲o̲ ̲I̲ ̲n̲e̲v̲e̲r̲ ̲l̲i̲k̲e̲d̲ ̲h̲i̲m̲ and avoided his company.
option_4: He was always been a grumpy man, so I never liked him a̲n̲d̲ ̲a̲v̲o̲i̲d̲e̲d̲ ̲h̲i̲s̲ ̲c̲o̲m̲p̲a̲n̲y̲.
solution:
Answer: He was always been a grumpy man, so I never liked him and avoided his company.
Explanation:

  • The phrase “was always been” is grammatically incorrect because it incorrectly combines the past tense “was” with the perfect tense “been.”

  • Correct forms could be:

  • “He has always been a grumpy man...” (present perfect)

  • “He was always a grumpy man...” (simple past)

  • The error lies in the underlined portion "was always been" in option 1.

  • The other parts of the sentence are grammatically correct.

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
My younger brother were attending a short-term computer course these days.

(SSC CGL 2023 T-1 : 27 July Shift-1)
solution:
Answer: were attending

Solution:

The subject "My younger brother" is singular, so the verb should also be singular.

The phrase "these days" indicates a present ongoing action, so the correct verb form is "is attending" (present continuous tense).

Hence, "were attending" is incorrect here.

Correct sentence:
"My younger brother is attending a short-term computer course these days."

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don’t find any error, mark ‘No error’ as your answer.
We feed the horse oats for a week because it had eaten all the hay.

(SSC CPO 2023 T-1 : 3 Oct Shift-1 (9 to 11 AM))
option_1: it had eaten all the hay
option_3: We feed the horse oats
solution:
The part that contains an error in the given sentence is: We feed the horse oats

The corrected sentence would be: "We fed the horse oats for a week because it had eaten all the hay."

Explanation: The error is in the tense consistency. The first part of the sentence indicates past tense ("it had eaten all the hay"), so the rest of the sentence should also be in the past tense. Therefore, it should be "We fed the horse oats for a week" instead of "We feed the horse oats for a week."

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don’t find any error, mark ‘No error’ as your answer.
Luckily, I managed to get a room in the college hostel, and I move in there.

(SSC CPO 2023 T-1 : 4 Oct Shift-1 (9 to 11 AM))
option_1: and I move in there
option_4: Luckily, I managed to get a room
solution:
The part of the sentence that contains an error is: and I move in there
The error lies in the tense agreement. The sentence starts in the past tense with "managed," so the subsequent action should also be in the past tense. Therefore, it should be "and I moved in there" instead of "and I move in there."
So, the corrected sentence would be: "Luckily, I managed to get a room in the college hostel, and I moved in there."

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don’t find any error, mark ‘No error’ as your answer.
Anant was telling a story about his most recent exploits when a tree branch break the living room window.

(SSC CPO 2023 T-1 : 4 Oct Shift-2 (12_30 to 2_30 PM))
option_2: about his most recent exploits
option_3: when a tree branch break the living room window
option_4: Anant was telling a story
solution:
The part that contains the error is: "when a tree branch break the living room window"
The correct form should be: "when a tree branch broke the living room window"
The main clause of the sentence is in the past tense: "Anant was telling a story." When narrating events in the past, it's essential to maintain consistency in verb tense throughout the sentence. Therefore, the verb in the subordinate clause "when a tree branch..." should also be in the past tense to indicate that the action happened before or simultaneously with the main event. In this case, the correct past tense form of the verb "break" is "broke."
The corrected sentence would be: "Anant was telling a story about his most recent exploits when a tree branch broke the living room window."

question:

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been underlined and given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
I̲f̲ ̲h̲e̲ ̲w̲i̲l̲l̲ ̲c̲o̲m̲e̲ early, w̲e̲ ̲w̲i̲l̲l̲ leave o̲n̲ ̲t̲i̲m̲e̲.

"If he comes early, we will leave on time."

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
After I complete my training program / I will have been joining a team of astronauts / and preparing to / embark on a mission to Mars.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 4_Sept_Shift-3)
option_2: I will have been joining a team of astronauts
option_3: embark on a mission to Mars
option_4: After I complete my training program
solution:

Solution: The segment "I will have been joining a team of astronauts" contains the grammatical error.

The phrase uses future perfect continuous tense ("will have been joining"), which is incorrect here. The correct tense should be simple future tense:

question:

question:

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains an error.
Will Ramya / had completed / that work / by 2025?

(SSC CPO 2023 T-1 : 5 Oct Shift-1 (9 to 11 AM))
solution:
The error lies in segment (a) "had completed."

The use of "had completed" implies past perfect tense, which is not appropriate in this context. Since the sentence is about an action that will be completed in the future (by 2025), the correct tense to use is future perfect. Therefore, the correct form of the verb should be "will have completed."

The corrected sentence would be: "Will Ramya have completed that work by 2025?"

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don’t find any error, mark ‘No error’ as your answer.
(1) He could / (2) be pass his exams / (3) if he studied harder. / (4) No error

(SSC CPO 2023 T-1 : 5 Oct Shift-3 (4 to 6 PM))
solution:
The correct answer is: “he studied harder.”

When "if" is used to introduce a condition in a sentence, the verb tense that follows is often the simple present tense. This is because the simple present tense is commonly used to express general truths, habitual actions, or future actions that are likely to happen.

Therefore, the correct sentence is: “He could be pass his exam if he study harder.”

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been underlined and given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
M̲y̲ relatives s̲h̲a̲l̲l̲ have r̲e̲a̲c̲h̲e̲d̲ Amritsar b̲y̲ ̲n̲o̲w̲.̲

(SSC MTS 2023 : 5_Sept_Shift-1)
solution:
Answer: shall

Solution:

The correct sentence should be:
"My relatives must have reached Amritsar by now."

Explanation:

  • The phrase "by now" indicates a strong assumption about a completed action in the present based on current evidence or expectation.

  • In such contexts, we use "must have + past participle" to show that something has very likely already happened.

Why "shall have reached" is incorrect here:

  • "Shall have reached" is the future perfect tense, used for actions that will be completed before a specific time in the future.

  • But "by now" refers to the present moment, not the future — so future perfect tense is not appropriate.

  • Therefore, "shall have reached" does not match the meaning intended by "by now".

Correct usage:

  • ✅ "They must have reached by now." (strong logical assumption — correct)

  • ❌ "They shall have reached by now." (illogical mix of future and present — incorrect)

Grammar rule:
Use "must have + V3" for logical assumptions about a completed action in the recent past or present (with expressions like "by now", "already", etc.).

question:
The following sentence has been divided into four parts. Identify the part that contains an error.
(A) We are living / (B) here since / (C) the summer / (D) of last year.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 5_Sept_Shift-1)
solution:
Answer: Option 3 – A

Solution:

The sentence is:
(A) We are living / (B) here since / (C) the summer / (D) of last year.

Let’s understand the rule being violated here:

  • The word “since” is used with Perfect tenses (especially Present Perfect Continuous) when indicating the starting point of an action that continues into the present.

  • The tense "We are living" (Present Continuous) is incorrect with "since".

Correct usage:

  • ❌ "We are living here since..." → Incorrect

  • ✅ "We have been living here since..." → Correct Present Perfect Continuous tense

Corrected sentence:

"We have been living here since the summer of last year."

So, the error is in Part A – We are living, which should be "We have been living".

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains an error.
They had been dancing / for an hour / when our dance teacher / had arrived.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 5_Sept_Shift-2)
solution:
Answer: Option 3 – had arrived

Solution:

The sentence is:
"They had been dancing / for an hour / when our dance teacher / had arrived."

Let’s analyse the tenses:

  • "They had been dancing" – past perfect continuous – correct, indicating an action that started in the past and continued up to a point. ✅

  • "for an hour" – duration – correct. ✅

  • "when our dance teacher had arrived" – ❌ this is incorrect.

Rule:

In past perfect tense structures involving two actions in the past:

  • The earlier action uses past perfect

  • The later action uses simple past

Here:

  • "They had been dancing" = ongoing earlier action ✅

  • So, the teacher's arrival is the later event, and must be in simple past, not past perfect

Correct sentence:

"They had been dancing for an hour when our dance teacher arrived."

So, the error is in "had arrived", which should be "arrived" – making Option 3 the correct answer.

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
Jaya said that she will become topper in her class.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 5_Sept_Shift-3)
solution:
Answer: Option 4 – she will become topper

Solution:

The sentence is:
"Jaya said that she will become topper in her class."

This is a case of indirect speech in the past tense ("Jaya said"), so the verb tense in the reported clause must follow backshift of tense.

  • "will" should change to "would" in reported speech.

  • Also, "become topper" is missing an article. It should be "become the topper".

Correct sentence:

"Jaya said that she would become the topper in her class."

So, the errors are:

  • "will" → "would" (tense error in indirect speech)

  • Missing "the" before "topper"

Hence, the error is in Option 4 – she will become topper.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
This is the first time / I ate such / a tasty cake.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 6_Sept_Shift-1)
option_3: This is the first time
solution:
Answer: Option 1 – I ate such

Solution:

The sentence is:
"This is the first time / I ate such / a tasty cake."

This sentence uses the phrase "This is the first time...", which refers to a present perfect experience.
So, the verb in the next part should be in the present perfect tense, not simple past.

  • ❌ "I ate such" → incorrect tense

  • ✅ "I have eaten such" → correct usage

Correct sentence:

"This is the first time I have eaten such a tasty cake."

Therefore, the error is in Option 1 – I ate such. It should be "I have eaten such".

question:
The following sentence has been divided into four parts. Identify the part that contains an error.
(A) He will come / (B) and receive you / (C) at the station / (D) when you will arrive.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 6_Sept_Shift-3)
solution:
Answer: (2) D
Solution:
• The error is in part D: "when you will arrive"
• In English grammar, when we talk about the future using a time clause (introduced by words like when, after, before, as soon as, until), we do not use "will" in the time clause
• Instead, we use the simple present tense to refer to a future action in such cases

Correct phrase:
"when you arrive" ✅ (not "when you will arrive" ❌)

Correct sentence:
"He will come and receive you at the station when you arrive."

Grammar Rule:
In complex sentences that talk about future events, the main clause uses "will", and the time clause uses present tense even though it refers to the future

Example:
• I will call you when I reach the office. ✅
• I will call you when I will reach the office. ❌

Therefore, the correct answer is (2) D ✅

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been underlined and given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
A̲s̲ ̲s̲o̲o̲n̲ ̲a̲s̲ I s̲h̲a̲l̲l̲ ̲w̲i̲n̲ the lottery, I h̲o̲p̲e̲ to buy a̲ ̲F̲e̲r̲r̲a̲r̲i̲.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 6_Sept_Shift-3)
solution:
Answer: (2) shall win
Solution:
• The phrase "As soon as I shall win the lottery" is grammatically incorrect because of incorrect use of "shall" in a time clause
• In English grammar, when a time clause begins with words like "as soon as", "when", "before", "after", etc., we use the simple present tense, even if the action refers to the future
• So instead of "shall win", we should use "win"

Correct sentence:
"As soon as I win the lottery, I hope to buy a Ferrari."

Grammar rule:
In future time clauses, use present tense (not future tense) after time expressions like as soon as, when, before, after
Example:
• Correct – As soon as he arrives, we will start the meeting.
• Incorrect – As soon as he will arrive, we will start the meeting.

Hence, the error is in (2) shall win, and the correct form is "win" ✅

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
The scooter that / I am using / these days is belonging / to my brother.

(SSC CGL 2022 T-1 : 8 Dec Shift-4)
solution:
Answer: these days is belonging

Explanation:

  • The verb belong is a stative verb and isn’t used in continuous tenses.

  • Instead of “is belonging,” we use the simple present “belongs.”

Correct sentence:

question:
The following sentence has been divided into four parts. Identify the part that contains an error.
(A) Four divided by / (B) two is coming / (C) out to / (D) be two.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 8_Sept_Shift-2)
solution:
Answer: (2) B
Solution:
• The phrase "two is coming" in part (B) is incorrect because the verb phrase "is coming" does not fit with a mathematical division statement.
• In a division sentence like this, we use "is" to indicate equality or the result of the operation, not "is coming".
• The correct phrase should be: "two is" (e.g., "Four divided by two is two") or "equals two".
• Using "is coming" suggests a continuous or future action, which is not appropriate for stating a mathematical fact or result.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains an error.
She was writing / a letter to her grandmother / when the power / gone out.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 8_Sept_Shift-2)
option_3: a letter to her grandmother
solution:
Answer: (2) gone out
Solution:
• The error is in the phrase "gone out" because it lacks the correct auxiliary verb for the past tense in this sentence.
• The correct form should be "had gone out" or "went out" depending on the tense used.
• Since the sentence uses past continuous tense ("She was writing"), the event that interrupted it should be in the simple past tense:

  • Correct: "when the power went out."

  • Incorrect: "when the power gone out."
    • Therefore, segment (2) contains the grammatical error.
    • Correct sentence: "She was writing a letter to her grandmother when the power went out."

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
I shall be playing for four hours.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 8_Sept_Shift-3)
solution:
Answer: (1) shall be playing
Solution:
• The phrase "shall be playing" is incorrect here because "shall" is generally used with first person singular and plural (I/we) to express future simple, but in modern English, "will" is preferred for future continuous tense in most cases.
• More importantly, "shall" is less commonly used with continuous tenses in everyday English.
• The sentence would be better as "I will be playing for four hours."

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains an error.
Mr Sharma would have left / the station / by this time / tomorrow.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 8_Sept_Shift-3)
option_4: Mr Sharma would have left
solution:
Answer: (4) Mr Sharma would have left
Solution:
• The error is in the phrase "Mr Sharma would have left" when used with "tomorrow".
• The future perfect tense (would have + past participle) is not used with "tomorrow" as it indicates a future time; instead, the future perfect tense with "will" is correct.
• The correct sentence should be:
"Mr Sharma will have left the station by this time tomorrow."
• Other parts (the station, by this time, tomorrow) are correct.
• Hence, segment (4) contains the grammatical error.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
A book market / was been operated by some readers / in the street when / they reached there.

(SSC CGL 2022 T-1 : 9 Dec Shift-2)
option_2: was been operated by some readers
solution:
Answer: was been operated by some readers

Explanation:
The error lies in the passive‐continuous form:

  • In past passive continuous you need was being + past participle, not “was been.”

  • Being (present participle) shows the ongoing action; “been” is the past participle and cannot replace it.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
“Mrs. Pooja is / very busy at / the moment.” / “All right. I had been waiting.”

(SSC CPO 2022 T-1 : 9 Nov Shift-2)
option_2: “All right. I had been waiting.”
solution:
Answer: 2 ("All right. I had been waiting.")

Solution (Correct Option - 2: "All right. I had been waiting.")
The error is in the tense usage. The phrase "I had been waiting" is in the past perfect continuous tense, which is only used when referring to an action that was ongoing before another past action.

But in this context, the action of waiting is still relevant to the present, so the correct tense should be present perfect continuous:
✔ "I have been waiting."

Correct sentence:
“Mrs. Pooja is very busy at the moment.”
“All right. I have been waiting.”


Had been waiting – past perfect continuous; used when one past action occurs before another.
Have been waiting – present perfect continuous; used when the action started in the past and continues to the present.

question:

(SSC CPO 2024 T-2 (8 Mar))
option_2: to be quiet while she
option_3: The teacher asked the class
solution:
Explanation:

  • The sentence starts in the past tense: “The teacher asked…”

  • Therefore, the rest of the sentence should maintain the same tense for consistency.

  • However, the segment “but nobody is listening” is in the present continuous tense, which is incorrect in this past context.

🔁 Corrected version:
“…but nobody was listening.”

Thus, the segment “but nobody is listening” contains the grammatical error.

question:
Identify the segment in the sentence which contains a grammatical error.
It is time someone takes concrete steps to alleviate the problem of unemployment in the country.

(SSC CPO 2023 T-2)
option_1: It is time someone takes
solution:
Solution:
The error is in the segment "It is time someone takes".
After the phrase "It is time", the verb should be in the past tense, even though the action refers to the present or future. This is a grammatical structure used to express urgency or recommendation.

So, instead of "takes", it should be "took".

Correct sentence:
"It is time someone took concrete steps to alleviate the problem of unemployment in the country."

Option A: It is time someone takes – ❌ incorrect tense (should be "took")
Option B: concrete steps to alleviate – ✔ correct
Option C: the problem of unemployment – ✔ correct
Option D: in the country – ✔ correct

Answer: Option A (It is time someone takes).

question:
In the given sentence, several segments have been underlined. One of these underlined segments is grammatically incorrect in context of its usage in the sentence. Identify the INCORRECT segment from the following options.
The mayor stated that the city council was considering several proposals t̲o̲ ̲a̲d̲d̲r̲e̲s̲s̲ ̲t̲r̲a̲f̲f̲i̲c̲ ̲c̲o̲n̲g̲e̲s̲t̲i̲o̲n̲,̲ i̲n̲c̲l̲u̲d̲i̲n̲g̲ ̲t̲h̲e̲ ̲i̲n̲t̲r̲o̲d̲u̲c̲t̲i̲o̲n̲ ̲o̲f̲ ̲a̲ ̲n̲e̲w̲ ̲p̲u̲b̲l̲i̲c̲ ̲t̲r̲a̲n̲s̲p̲o̲r̲t̲a̲t̲i̲o̲n̲ ̲s̲y̲s̲t̲e̲m̲ and t̲h̲e̲ ̲e̲x̲p̲a̲n̲s̲i̲o̲n̲ ̲o̲f̲ ̲b̲i̲k̲e̲ ̲l̲a̲n̲e̲s̲,̲ b̲u̲t̲ ̲h̲e̲ ̲d̲o̲e̲s̲n̲'̲t̲ ̲b̲e̲l̲i̲e̲v̲e̲ ̲a̲n̲y̲ ̲o̲f̲ ̲t̲h̲e̲m̲ ̲w̲i̲l̲l̲ ̲b̲e̲ ̲e̲f̲f̲e̲c̲t̲i̲v̲e̲.

(SSC CPO 2022 T-2)
option_2: the expansion of bike lanes,
option_3: but he doesn't believe any of them will be effective
option_4: including the introduction of a new public transportation system
solution:
Solution:

  • The sentence is:
    The mayor stated that the city council was considering several proposals to address traffic congestion, including the introduction of a new public transportation system and the expansion of bike lanes, but he doesn't believe any of them will be effective.

  • The sentence is mostly correct except for tense inconsistency in the last segment.

  • The first part uses past tense reporting ("stated," "was considering"), so the last part should also follow past tense for consistency.

  • The segment "but he doesn't believe any of them will be effective" is in present tense, which is inconsistent. It should be "but he didn't believe any of them would be effective."

  • Therefore, the incorrect segment is: "but he doesn't believe any of them will be effective."

Answer: (c) but he doesn't believe any of them will be effective

question:

question:

question:

solution:

question:

question:

option_2: but both do not take off
option_4: Rishi and Rahul are twins
solution:
Explanation:
The error lies in the segment: "but both do not take off"

  • The phrasal verb "take off" is incorrect in this context.

  • The intended meaning is to resemble or show traits similar to someone, for which the correct phrasal verb is "take after".

  • "Take off" typically means to leave the ground (for aircraft) or to become successful, which does not fit the sentence’s context.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
Professor Gupta is an authority / on income tax because / he cannot exercise / any authority over his family.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-2 (30 April))
option_3: any authority over his family
option_4: Professor Gupta is an authority
solution:
Explanation:

The sentence is logically inconsistent and grammatically confusing due to the connector "because" used after "authority on income tax."

  • The first part says: "Professor Gupta is an authority on income tax" – meaning he is an expert in the subject.

  • But then it says "because he cannot exercise any authority over his family" – which is illogical. Not being able to control one's family has no causal link to being an authority on income tax.

So, the grammatical structure itself is correct, but the use of "because" makes the sentence illogical, and that’s where the error lies.

Better version:

"Professor Gupta is an authority on income tax, although he cannot exercise any authority over his family."

This uses "although" to contrast two unrelated facts, which makes more logical and grammatical sense.

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
Ramayana is an ancient Sanskrit epic; it is believed to be written around 500 BC to 100 BC.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (01-July Shift 2))
solution:
In the sentence, "Ramayana" should be written as "the Ramayana" to indicate that we're referring to a specific epic, not just any random "Ramayana."

When referring to a specific, well-known work like this, the definite article "the" is needed to specify that we are talking about the Ramayana (the particular ancient Sanskrit epic).

So the corrected sentence would be:

"The Ramayana is an ancient Sanskrit epic; it is believed to be written around 500 BC to 100 BC."

Why we use "the":

  • "The" is used when referring to something unique or specific (in this case, the specific epic "Ramayana").

  • Without "the," it would imply that "Ramayana" is just any random term, which isn't the case here, as we are talking about a famous and specific text.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains an error.
In this cold weather, / there’s nothing / like good / cup of coffee.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (08-July Shift 3))
solution:
Correct Answer: like good

Explanation:

  • The error lies in the segment "like good" because the phrase is incomplete without an article before the adjective-noun phrase.

  • The correct expression should be: "like a good cup of coffee".

  • In English, when using "like" to compare or express preference, and it is followed by an adjective and countable noun (e.g. good cup), we need to include an article (“a”) before it.

✅ Correct sentence: "In this cold weather, there’s nothing like a good cup of coffee."

Summary of the Error:

  • “good cup” is a singular countable noun phrase and requires an article.

  • The omission of “a” makes the sentence grammatically incorrect.

question:

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
The workers had been repairing / the mall road in / town for / several days now.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.1_30-Sep_Shift-1)
option_3: The workers had been repairing
solution:
Correct Answer: The workers had been repairing

Explanation:
The sentence uses the phrase "several days now," indicating that the action started in the past and is still continuing at present. For such ongoing actions up to now, the present perfect continuous tense is appropriate.

  • "Had been repairing" is the past perfect continuous tense, which is used for actions that were ongoing before another past event. It is not suitable here because the action continues to the present.

  • The correct tense should be "have been repairing" (present perfect continuous).

Correct sentence:
The workers have been repairing the mall road in town for several days now.

Part of speech with error:
Verb tense (incorrect use of past perfect continuous instead of present perfect continuous).

question:
